2.original_verse: The Blessed One said: How does this faint heart come to you in time of difficulty? This is not suitable for a noble one; it is not heavenly, and brings on disgrace.
2.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna critiques Arjuna's despondency, emphasizing the importance of courage and action as befitting a warrior and a noble soul.

3.original_verse: Do not become a cowardly eunuch, Son of Pritha; this is not fitting for you. Let go of this lowly weakness of the heart and stand up, Scorcher of the Enemy!
3.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna urges Arjuna to cast off his weakness, invoking his responsibility and valor as a Kshatriya (warrior).

11.original_verse: The Blessed One said: You have grieved for those who should not be grieved for, yet you speak words of wisdom. The wise do not grieve for the living or the dead.
11.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna introduces the core teaching of detachment by emphasizing that grief arises from ignorance of the eternal nature of the self.

12.original_verse: Never was there a time when I did not exist, nor you, nor these kings; and never will there be a time when we shall cease to exist.
12.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna highlights the immortality of the soul, teaching that existence transcends birth and death.

13.original_verse: Just as the embodied self passes through childhood, youth, and old age, so also it passes into another body. The wise are not deluded by this.
13.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna explains the transmigration of the soul, likening the changes of the body to the stages of life, to encourage detachment.

14.original_verse: Contact of the senses with their objects produces cold and heat, pleasure and pain. They come and go and are impermanent. Endure them, O Bharata.
14.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna advises equanimity in the face of sensory experiences, stressing their temporary nature.

15.original_verse: The person whom these do not disturb, O Chief among men, and who remains the same in pleasure and pain, is wise and fit for immortality.
15.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna describes the state of equanimity as essential for spiritual liberation and the realization of immortality.

16.original_verse: The unreal has no existence; the real never ceases to be. The seers of truth have concluded the nature of both.
16.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna introduces the distinction between the eternal reality of the soul and the transience of the material world.

17.original_verse: Know that to be indestructible by which all this is pervaded. None can destroy the imperishable self.
17.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: The soul is described as eternal and indestructible, reinforcing the idea of its transcendence over physical destruction.

18.original_verse: These bodies of the eternal, imperishable, and incomprehensible embodied self are said to have an end. Therefore, fight, O Bharata.
18.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna contrasts the temporary nature of the body with the eternal self, encouraging Arjuna to perform his duty.

19.original_verse: He who thinks that the self kills, and he who thinks that it is killed, are both ignorant. The self kills not, nor is it killed.
19.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna emphasizes that the self is beyond action and unaffected by physical processes like killing or being killed.

20.original_verse: The self is never born, nor does it die. It does not come into existence, nor cease to be. It is unborn, eternal, changeless, and ancient; it is not killed when the body is killed.
20.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna affirms the timeless nature of the self, untouched by the cycle of birth and death.

21.original_verse: He who knows that the self is indestructible, eternal, unborn, and immutable—how can that person kill or cause to kill, O Partha?
21.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna questions the logic of Arjuna’s grief, pointing out that the eternal self cannot be harmed.

22.original_verse: Just as a person casts off worn-out garments and puts on new ones, so the embodied self casts off worn-out bodies and enters others that are new.
22.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna uses the metaphor of changing garments to illustrate the process of reincarnation.

23.original_verse: Weapons do not cut it, fire does not burn it, water does not wet it, wind does not dry it.
23.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: The self is described as invulnerable to physical forces, highlighting its transcendental nature.

24.original_verse: It cannot be cut, burned, wetted, or dried. It is eternal, all-pervading, stable, immovable, and timeless.
24.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna emphasizes the unchanging, eternal nature of the self, which pervades all existence.

25.original_verse: It is said to be unmanifest, unthinkable, and unchanging. Therefore, knowing it to be such, you should not grieve.
25.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: The self is beyond perception and thought; understanding this truth liberates one from grief.

26.original_verse: But if you think of it as being perpetually born and perpetually dying, even then, O Mighty-armed, you should not grieve.
26.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Even within the framework of mortality, grief is unwarranted as life is a cycle of continuity.

27.original_verse: For certain is death for the born, and certain is birth for the dead. Therefore, you should not grieve over the inevitable.
27.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna points out the inevitability of the life-death cycle, urging detachment and acceptance.

28.original_verse: Beings are unmanifest in their beginning, manifest in their middle state, and unmanifest again in their end, O Bharata. What is there to grieve over?
28.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna explains that existence is cyclical, with appearances being transient phases, and hence grieving over such impermanent states is unnecessary.

29.original_verse: Some look upon the self as a marvel, some speak of it as a marvel, some hear of it as a marvel, and yet others, even after hearing, do not understand it at all.
29.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: The self is described as an enigmatic and profound truth, appreciated fully only by a few, while most fail to grasp its essence.

30.original_verse: The self that dwells in all bodies can never be slain, O Bharata. Therefore, you should not grieve for any being.
30.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna reiterates the indestructibility of the self, urging Arjuna to abandon sorrow and act according to his duty.

31.original_verse: Further, looking at your own dharma, you should not waver, for there is nothing higher for a Kshatriya than a righteous war.
31.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna reminds Arjuna of his duty as a warrior, emphasizing that fighting in a righteous war aligns with his dharma.

32.original_verse: Fortunate are the Kshatriyas who are called to fight in such a battle, which comes unsought as an open door to heaven.
32.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna presents the battle as an opportunity for glory and spiritual elevation, emphasizing its rare and noble nature.

33.original_verse: But if you will not fight this righteous battle, then, having abandoned your dharma and honor, you will incur sin.
33.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna warns Arjuna of the spiritual and moral consequences of abandoning his duty, framing inaction as sinful.

34.original_verse: People will recount your everlasting dishonor, and for a man of honor, dishonor is worse than death.
34.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna appeals to Arjuna’s sense of honor, emphasizing the disgrace and shame that inaction would bring.

35.original_verse: The great warriors will think that you have withdrawn from the battle out of fear, and those who once held you in high esteem will speak of you with contempt.
35.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna underscores the perception of cowardice and the loss of respect that would follow Arjuna’s retreat.

36.original_verse: Your enemies will slander you in unseemly words and deride your strength. What could be more painful than that?
36.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna appeals to Arjuna’s warrior pride, warning him of the humiliation and mockery he would face from his enemies.

37.original_verse: If you are killed, you will attain heaven; if you are victorious, you will enjoy the earth. Therefore, arise, O son of Kunti, resolved to fight!
37.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna motivates Arjuna by framing both outcomes—death or victory—as beneficial and urging him to act with resolve.

38.original_verse: Treating alike pleasure and pain, gain and loss, victory and defeat, then prepare for battle. Thus you will not incur sin.
38.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna introduces the concept of equanimity, emphasizing that detachment from outcomes ensures freedom from sin.

39.original_verse: This wisdom has been taught to you from the perspective of Sankhya. Now listen to it from the perspective of yoga, which frees one from the bondage of action.
39.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna transitions to explaining karma yoga, highlighting its role in transcending the limitations of action and attachment.

40.original_verse: In this path, no effort is ever wasted, and no failure arises. Even a little of this practice protects one from great fear.
40.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna emphasizes the infallibility of the yoga path, assuring Arjuna of its lasting benefits and protective nature.

41.original_verse: In this, O Joy of the Kurus, there is a single, unwavering conviction. The thoughts of the irresolute are many-branched and endless.
41.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna emphasizes the importance of a resolute and focused mind in the path of knowledge and action, contrasting it with the scattered nature of the irresolute.

42.original_verse: O Partha, the unwise, enchanted by the flowery words of the Vedas, and attached to desires, consider heaven as the supreme goal.
42.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna criticizes those who are preoccupied with material rewards and superficial interpretations of the Vedas, neglecting deeper spiritual truths.

43.original_verse: They are full of desire and intent on heaven; they utter speech that leads to actions that yield rebirth as the fruit of their works and are full of specific rituals.
43.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Such individuals are bound by rituals and desire-driven actions, which perpetuate the cycle of birth and death, preventing liberation.

44.original_verse: The resolute wisdom of those who are too attached to enjoyment and power is not established in the Self, O Arjuna.
44.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Attachment to power and pleasure obstructs the realization of the Self, leading to spiritual stagnation.

45.original_verse: The Vedas deal with the three qualities of nature. Be free from these qualities, O Arjuna, and free from duality, ever firm in purity, independent of possessions, and possessed of the Self.
45.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna urges Arjuna to transcend the gunas (qualities) and dualities of nature, focusing instead on inner purity and self-realization.

46.original_verse: To the knower of the Self, the Vedas are as useful as a small reservoir of water in a flood.
46.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna conveys that for one established in self-knowledge, the rituals and instructions of the Vedas lose their significance, akin to a small reservoir being redundant during a flood.

47.original_verse: Your right is to perform action alone, never to its fruits. Let not the fruits of action be your motive, nor let your attachment be to inaction.
47.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna introduces the concept of Nishkama Karma (selfless action), advising Arjuna to focus on duty without attachment to outcomes.

48.original_verse: Remaining steadfast in yoga, O Arjuna, perform actions, abandoning attachment and remaining even-minded in success and failure. This equanimity is called yoga.
48.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna defines yoga as equanimity in all circumstances, achieved through detachment and focused action.

49.original_verse: Action is far inferior to the yoga of wisdom, O Arjuna. Take refuge in wisdom. Those who are motivated by fruits are miserable.
49.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna extols the superiority of wisdom over mere ritualistic actions, urging Arjuna to embrace higher knowledge.

50.original_verse: One who is steadfast in wisdom casts off both good and evil deeds here. Therefore, strive for yoga. Yoga is skill in action.
50.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna describes yoga as skillful and detached action that transcends the duality of good and bad karma.

51.original_verse: The wise, steadfast in yoga, renounce the fruits of action. Freed from the bonds of birth, they reach a state beyond suffering.
51.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna highlights the liberation achieved through yoga, which frees one from rebirth and leads to ultimate bliss.

52.original_verse: When your intellect crosses beyond the mire of delusion, you shall become indifferent to what has been heard and what is yet to be heard.
52.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna explains that liberation from delusion leads to freedom from dependence on external teachings and rituals, as self-knowledge becomes paramount.

53.original_verse: When your intellect, bewildered by the Vedas, becomes unmoving and steady in contemplation, then you shall attain yoga.
53.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna points out that unwavering focus and contemplation lead to the realization of yoga, transcending confusion caused by ritualistic interpretations.

55.original_verse: The Blessed One said: When a man gives up all desires of the mind, O Partha, and is satisfied in the Self alone, then he is said to be steady in wisdom.
55.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna defines the wise as those who have renounced desires and found contentment within the Self, embodying inner fulfillment.

56.original_verse: He whose mind is not shaken by adversity, who does not hanker after pleasures, and who is free from attachment, fear, and anger, is called a sage of steady wisdom.
56.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna highlights equanimity and freedom from negative emotions as key attributes of the steadfast sage.

57.original_verse: He who is everywhere without attachment, on meeting with anything good or bad, who neither rejoices nor recoils, his wisdom is established.
57.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna describes the sage as someone unaffected by external circumstances, maintaining detachment and inner balance.

58.original_verse: When, like a tortoise drawing in its limbs, he withdraws his senses from the objects of sense, then his wisdom is established.
58.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna uses the tortoise metaphor to illustrate the wise person's ability to withdraw from sensory distractions.

59.original_verse: The objects of sense turn away from the abstinent man, leaving the longing behind; but his longing also turns away upon seeing the Supreme.
59.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna explains that desire subsides only when one experiences the higher joy of realizing the Supreme.

60.original_verse: The turbulent senses, O son of Kunti, violently carry away the mind of even a wise man striving for perfection.
60.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna warns about the power of the senses and the need for constant vigilance, even for those on the path of wisdom.

61.original_verse: Restraining them all, he should remain steadfast, intent on Me. His wisdom is steady whose senses are under control.
61.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna emphasizes the importance of sense control and devotion to achieve steadiness of wisdom.

62.original_verse: When a man dwells on the objects of sense, attachment to them arises; from attachment desire is born, and from desire anger is born.
62.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna outlines the chain reaction of attachment leading to desire, anger, and ultimately downfall.

63.original_verse: From anger comes delusion; from delusion, loss of memory; from loss of memory, destruction of intellect; and from the destruction of intellect, he perishes.
63.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna warns against anger, detailing how it leads to delusion and the eventual collapse of one's reasoning and progress.

64.original_verse: But the self-controlled man, moving among objects with senses under restraint and free from attachment and aversion, attains peace.
64.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna describes the state of peace attained through self-control and detachment from sensory pleasures.

65.original_verse: In that peace, all sorrow is destroyed; for the intellect of the tranquil-minded man soon becomes steady.
65.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna highlights the transformative power of peace in stabilizing the mind and removing sorrow.

66.original_verse: There is no wisdom in the unsteady; nor is there meditation in him. To the unmeditative there is no peace, and to the peaceless, how can there be happiness?
66.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna emphasizes the necessity of steadiness, meditation, and peace as prerequisites for true happiness.

67.original_verse: When the mind runs after the wandering senses, it carries away one’s wisdom as the wind carries away a boat on the water.
67.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna warns against the dangers of an uncontrolled mind and senses, likening it to a boat swept away by the wind.

68.original_verse: Therefore, O mighty-armed, his wisdom is steady whose senses are completely restrained from the objects of sense.
68.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna reinforces that sense control is essential for attaining steady wisdom and self-realization.

69.original_verse: What is night for all beings is the time of waking for the self-controlled; and the time of waking for all beings is night for the sage who sees.
69.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna uses this paradox to describe the enlightened state, where the wise perceive reality differently from ordinary people.

70.original_verse: He attains peace into whom all desires enter as waters enter the ocean, which, filled from all sides, remains unmoved—but not the desirer of desires.
70.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna compares the wise to an ocean that remains steady despite the inflow of desires, highlighting detachment as the key to peace.

71.original_verse: That man attains peace who, abandoning all desires, moves about without longing, without the sense of 'I' and 'mine.'
71.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna describes the state of liberation as one free from desires and ego, living in harmony with the Self.

72.original_verse: This is the divine state, O son of Pritha. Attaining this, one is not deluded. Being established in this even at the end, one attains Brahman.
72.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna concludes by describing the ultimate state of enlightenment, where one merges with Brahman and transcends delusion.

3.original_verse: Blameless One, in this world, a double foundation was taught by me in ancient times: the yoga of knowledge for those who follow samkhya, and the yoga of action for those who practise yoga.
3.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Introduces two paths: knowledge (jnana) and action (karma).

4.original_verse: One does not reach the state beyond action by abstaining from actions; nor does one reach fulfilment only by renunciation.
4.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Emphasizes the importance of action for spiritual progress.

5.original_verse: No one, not even for one moment, ever stands without acting; by virtue of the gunas born in nature, without willing it, everyone is made to perform action.
5.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Describes the inevitability of action driven by nature's gunas.

6.original_verse: The person who sits and subdues the active senses, while remembering and mindful of the objects of the senses: it is said that such a one is a confused self – who proceeds falsely.
6.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Critiques false asceticism and the lack of true control over senses.

7.original_verse: But, Arjuna, the one who begins to rein in the senses through the mind and who, without clinging, begins the yoga of action through the active senses, is unique.
7.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Highlights disciplined action and self-control.

8.original_verse: So perform action which is restrained, for this action is better than non-action; and even the working of your body would not succeed without action.
8.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Advises Arjuna on the necessity and superiority of disciplined action.

9.original_verse: Except for action whose end is sacrifice, this world is bound by action; without clinging, perform action towards this end of sacrifice, Son of Kunti.
9.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Explains the purpose of selfless action as a form of sacrifice.

10.original_verse: In ancient times, after he created sacrifices along with humans, the lord of beings said: ‘You shall create through this! May this be the cow who grants your desires.’
10.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Discusses the origins of sacrificial actions as foundational to human life.

11.original_verse: By this, may you cause the gods to be; and may the gods cause you to be. As you both sustain each other, you will reach the higher good.
11.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Mutual nourishment between humans and gods through sacrifices sustains the cosmic balance.

12.original_verse: As the gods are created by sacrifice, they will give you sought-after pleasures. The one who enjoys what is given by them but does not give to them is a thief.
12.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Those who consume resources without contributing back disrupt the natural order and are metaphorically 'thieves.'

13.original_verse: The true ones who eat the leftovers of the sacrifices are free from all evils; but the evil ones eat their own impurity, as they cook only for themselves.
13.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Sharing sacrificial remnants purifies the soul, while selfish consumption binds one to sin.

14.original_verse: Beings exist through food; Parjanya, the rain, is the source of food. Parjanya exists through sacrifice and sacrifice exists through action.
14.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: The interdependence of sacrifice, natural elements, and human survival emphasizes the necessity of actions.

15.original_verse: Know the origin of sacrificial action as Brahman, arising from the eternal nature of Brahman; thus all-pervading Brahman is eternally fixed in sacrifice.
15.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Sacrifice originates in the eternal knowledge of Brahman, linking it to the cosmic order.

16.original_verse: The one who does not set the wheel in motion here on earth lives uselessly, wanting to hurt, impassioned by the senses, Son of Pritha.
16.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Neglecting duty disrupts the cosmic wheel, leading to a life of selfishness and harm.

17.original_verse: The person who would be content with what comes unbidden and does not cling to the fruit of action is free, and not bound by action, even though active.
17.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Contentment with unbidden outcomes frees one from the bondage of actions.

18.original_verse: Without a need for external objects, content within himself, such a person does nothing and is free, even though engaged in action.
18.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Self-contentment leads to liberation, even amidst active engagement.

19.original_verse: Always perform action that is your duty, for action is superior to inaction; and without action, even the body would not survive.
19.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Action sustains life and is vital for fulfilling one's duties in the cosmic order.

20.original_verse: The enlightened king Janaka reached fulfillment by action. Consider how to maintain the world, Son of Pritha.
20.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: The example of Janaka demonstrates that action can lead to liberation and world maintenance.

21.original_verse: What the best person does is followed by others; people follow the example he sets.
21.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Leaders influence society, emphasizing the importance of setting virtuous examples.

22.original_verse: I do not have to perform any action in all the three worlds, nor is there anything unattained that must be attained; still, I remain active.
22.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Even the divine remains active to uphold the natural order and guide humanity.

23.original_verse: If I did not remain active, without ceasing, people would follow my path, Son of Pritha.
23.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Inactivity from a leader would misguide humanity, emphasizing the need for responsible action.

24.original_verse: If I stopped acting, these worlds would perish, and I would become the cause of chaos and the destruction of all beings.
24.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Abandoning action would result in chaos and destruction, emphasizing the necessity of responsible activity.

25.original_verse: The unwise perform action with attachment to results; the wise should act without attachment, for the welfare of the world.
25.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: The wise act selflessly for the greater good, contrasting the attachment of the unwise.

26.original_verse: The wise should not cause disruption in the understanding of the unwise; instead, they should act in accordance with duty, remaining unattached.
26.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: The wise must act without attachment and set an example for others, avoiding unnecessary confusion in the minds of the unwise.

27.original_verse: All actions are performed by the gunas of prakriti; but a person deluded by ego thinks, 'I am the doer.'
27.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Actions are driven by the qualities of nature, but ignorance leads one to falsely attribute doership to themselves.

28.original_verse: But one who knows the truth of the gunas and actions does not become attached, realizing that the gunas interact with the gunas.
28.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: The knowledgeable observe the natural interplay of qualities without developing attachments.

29.original_verse: Those deluded by the gunas of prakriti become attached to actions; the wise should not unsettle the ignorant whose knowledge is incomplete.
29.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: While ignorance fosters attachment, the wise must maintain calm and avoid disturbing the uninitiated.

30.original_verse: Renouncing all actions to me, with a mind that knows the self, without desire or a sense of possession, and free from lethargy, engage in battle.
30.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Surrendering actions to the divine and acting selflessly leads to liberation, even amidst worldly duties.

31.original_verse: Those who follow this teaching of mine with faith and without complaint are also released from the bonds of actions.
31.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Faithful adherence to divine teachings frees one from the cycle of karma.

32.original_verse: But those who criticize this teaching and do not follow it are deluded in all knowledge, and perish.
32.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Rejecting divine guidance results in ignorance and spiritual downfall.

33.original_verse: Even the wise act according to their nature; beings follow nature. What can restraint do?
33.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Actions are driven by inherent qualities of nature, and external restraints alone are insufficient.

34.original_verse: Attachment and aversion to sense objects arise from the gunas; one must not come under their sway, for they are obstacles on the path.
34.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Mastery over attachment and aversion is crucial for spiritual progress.

35.original_verse: Better is one’s own dharma, though imperfect, than the dharma of another well-performed; better is death in one’s own dharma; the dharma of another brings danger.
35.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: One's individual duty, however flawed, is preferable to adopting another's path, which can lead to harm.

36.original_verse: Arjuna said: But by what is one impelled to sin, even unwillingly, as if constrained by force, O Krishna?
36.speaker: Arjuna

commentary.shankaracharya: Arjuna questions the compelling forces that drive people towards wrongful actions against their will.

37.original_verse: Krishna said: It is desire, it is anger, born of the guna of rajas; insatiable and greatly wicked, know this to be the enemy here.
37.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Desire and anger, rooted in passion, are destructive forces obstructing spiritual progress.

38.original_verse: As fire is covered by smoke, as a mirror is obscured by dust, as the embryo is enveloped by the womb, so is this covered by that.
38.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Desire veils wisdom in the same way physical obstructions obscure clarity.

39.original_verse: Knowledge is covered by this eternal enemy of the wise, in the form of desire, which is an insatiable fire.
39.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Unfulfilled desires perpetually obscure wisdom, making them the eternal enemy of enlightenment.

40.original_verse: The senses, the mind, and the intellect are said to be its seat; covering knowledge through these, it deludes the embodied being.
40.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Desire operates through the senses, mind, and intellect, creating illusions and binding the self.

41.original_verse: So, Bull of the Bharatas: first rein in the senses; then strike down this evil one who destroys wisdom and discernment.
41.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna advises controlling the senses to weaken the power of desire, which hinders discernment and wisdom.

42.original_verse: They say that the senses are crucial; and the mind more crucial than the senses; and even more crucial than the mind is insight; and much more crucial than insight, is this [self].
42.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: The hierarchy of subtlety places the self above intellect, highlighting its supreme importance.

43.original_verse: Strong-Armed One, when you have learned what is higher than insight – the self, sustained through the self – then kill the enemy that takes the shape of desire and is hard to approach.
43.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna emphasizes self-mastery and advises overcoming desire through a disciplined and self-sustained mind.

1.original_verse: I declared this imperishable yoga to Vivasvat, god of the sun, and he told it to Manu, the first human, who told it to his son Ikshvaku.
1.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna reveals that the ancient teachings of yoga were passed down through divine lineage to preserve dharma.

2.original_verse: Scorcher of the Enemy, through many an age, the royal sages knew this yoga, obtained as it was through lineage; and then this yoga was lost to the world.
2.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: The lineage of dharma was disrupted, leading to the loss of the ancient yoga tradition.

3.original_verse: Today I tell this ancient yoga to you, since you are devoted to me, and since you are my friend. This is indeed the highest mystery.
3.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna emphasizes Arjuna’s devotion as the reason for revealing the sacred teachings to him.

4.original_verse: But your birth was later, and the birth of Vivasvat was earlier; how should I understand that you spoke it in the beginning?
4.speaker: Arjuna

commentary.shankaracharya: Arjuna questions Krishna’s claim of having passed down ancient knowledge, given Krishna's apparent later birth.

5.original_verse: Arjuna, many of my births have come and gone, and yours, too; while I know them all, you do not, Scorcher of the Enemy.
5.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna highlights the distinction between his divine omniscience and Arjuna's limited human memory.

6.original_verse: Although I am unborn, an imperishable self, and the Lord of all Beings, I govern my own earthly nature, and come into being by my own creative force.
6.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna describes his divine incarnation and creative force in manifesting in the world.

7.original_verse: Son of Bharata, whenever there is decline in dharma, and the absence of dharma increases, I create myself.
7.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna incarnates whenever dharma declines and adharma rises, to restore cosmic balance.

8.original_verse: I come into being from age to age with the purpose of fixing dharma – as a refuge for those who do good and as a doom for those who do evil.
8.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna’s incarnations serve to protect the righteous and eradicate evil.

9.original_verse: So Arjuna, when one who truly knows my divine birth and action leaves the body, that person does not go to birth again, but goes to me.
9.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Knowing Krishna’s divine nature liberates one from the cycle of rebirth.

10.original_verse: Thinking of me, resorting to me, many have reached my being, purified through the heated discipline of wisdom, their greed, fear and anger fully gone.
10.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Devotion to Krishna and self-purification lead to union with the divine.

11.original_verse: Son of Pritha, I devote myself to those who resort to me; in just the same way, people follow my path in all places.
11.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna reciprocates the devotion of his followers and is universally accessible.

12.original_verse: Longing for fulfillment through ritual acts, here in this world, they sacrifice to the gods; and in this mortal world, fulfillment born of such acts comes into being quickly indeed.
12.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Ritual acts and sacrifices yield worldly results, but are distinct from eternal liberation.

13.original_verse: The four castes were brought forth by me, distributing gunas with actions; although I am the Creator of this world, know me as the Imperishable One who does not act.
13.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna acknowledges creating social orders but remains unattached and imperishable.

14.original_verse: Actions do not stain me, nor do I desire the fruits of actions. So too, the one who knows me is not bound by actions.
14.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Detachment from results liberates one from the bonds of karma.

15.original_verse: Action was undertaken by the ancient ones who knew this and who sought freedom; so undertake action as was done by the ancient ones in earlier times.
15.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna advises Arjuna to follow the path of the ancient sages in performing dutiful action.

16.original_verse: Even the poets are confused by this, saying, ‘What is action? What is non-action?’ I tell you, when you know this action, you will be freed from impurity.
16.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Action and inaction are subtle concepts, and understanding them leads to liberation from impurities of karma.

17.original_verse: One should have watchful insight into action, watchful insight into wrong action, and watchful insight into non-action. The way of action is hard to fathom.
17.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Insight into actions, their consequences, and inaction requires deep discernment, making the path challenging but rewarding.

18.original_verse: Among humans, the person who sees non-action in action, and action in non-action, has insight; and that person has undertaken all action.
18.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Seeing stillness in activity and activity in stillness demonstrates true wisdom and mastery over actions.

19.original_verse: The wise call that person insightful, one who’s every act is free of desire, and whose acts have been burned by the fire of wisdom.
19.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Acts performed without desire and illuminated by wisdom are the hallmark of an enlightened soul.

20.original_verse: Giving up all attachment to the fruit of actions, ever content, depending on nothing, though engaged in action, such a person does not act at all.
20.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: A selfless person, detached from outcomes, remains untainted by actions even while performing them.

21.original_verse: Devoid of desire, with a disciplined mind and body, and renouncing all possessions, such a person incurs no sin while performing action.
21.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Renunciation of desires and disciplined conduct purify actions, rendering them sinless.

22.original_verse: Satisfied with whatever comes unasked, rising above dualities, free from envy, the same in success and failure, even when acting, such a person is not bound.
22.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Equanimity and contentment liberate one from the bonds of success, failure, and desire.

23.original_verse: The actions of a person who is free from attachment, with their thoughts established in wisdom and acting for the sake of sacrifice, dissolve entirely.
23.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Actions performed selflessly and with wisdom merge into the eternal, leaving no residue of karma.

24.original_verse: For the one who sees Brahman in all actions, the act of offering, the offered material, the fire, the offering itself, and the one who offers all become Brahman.
24.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Seeing unity in all aspects of action transforms every deed into a divine act.

25.original_verse: Some offer sacrifices to the gods; others, in the fire of Brahman, offer themselves through the fire of yoga.
25.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Sacrifices can take many forms, but all lead towards self-realization when performed with dedication.

26.original_verse: Others offer hearing and other senses as sacrifices in the fire of restraint, and still others offer sound and other sense objects in the fires of the senses.
26.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Mastery over senses is itself a form of sacrifice, leading to spiritual purification.

27.original_verse: Others, with disciplined minds, offer all the functions of the senses and the vital breath in the fire of the yoga of self-control.
27.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Self-control, channeling all energies towards discipline, becomes a higher form of sacrifice.

28.original_verse: Some perform sacrifices with material possessions, others through austerity, others through the yoga of meditation, and still others through study and knowledge.
28.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Sacrifices take various forms but are unified in their purpose of spiritual elevation.

29.original_verse: Others offer as a sacrifice the outgoing breath in the incoming, and the incoming in the outgoing, restraining the flow of breaths, solely absorbed in the regulation of breath.
29.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Breath regulation and mindfulness become sacred acts when performed with focus and devotion.

30.original_verse: The yogis who eat what remains from the sacrifice go to eternal Brahman; those who do not sacrifice in this world are not even this world’s inhabitants. How can they be of another world, Son of Pritha?
30.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Sacrifice purifies and elevates the soul towards Brahman; neglecting it leads to spiritual stagnation and loss.

31.original_verse: Those men who ever follow this teaching of Mine with faith and without cavil, they also become freed from actions.
31.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Following Krishna’s teachings with faith and without criticism leads to liberation from the effects of actions.

32.original_verse: But those who, decrying this, do not follow My teaching, know them—who are deluded about all knowledge and who are devoid of discrimination—to have gone to ruin.
32.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Those who reject Krishna’s teachings and remain in ignorance are doomed to spiritual downfall.

33.original_verse: Superior is knowledge-sacrifice to material sacrifice, O Scorcher of Enemies. All actions in their totality culminate in knowledge.
33.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Sacrifices rooted in knowledge are higher than material sacrifices; wisdom is the ultimate goal of all actions.

34.original_verse: Understand this through humble submission, inquiry, and service. The wise who have realized the truth will instruct you in knowledge.
34.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Approach the wise with humility and questions to gain true knowledge and spiritual insight.

35.original_verse: Having known this, O Son of Pandu, you will not be deluded like this again, and by this you will see all beings in your Self and also in Me.
35.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: True knowledge dispels delusion and reveals the unity of all beings in the Self and Krishna.

36.original_verse: Even if you are the most sinful of all sinners, you will cross over all evil by the raft of knowledge alone.
36.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: The power of knowledge is such that it can absolve even the greatest sins and guide one to purity.

37.original_verse: As the blazing fire reduces fuel to ashes, O Arjuna, so does the fire of knowledge reduce all actions to ashes.
37.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Knowledge burns away the residue of all actions, leaving the seeker purified and free.

38.original_verse: In this world, there is no purifier like knowledge. One who is perfected in yoga finds this in due time within themselves.
38.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Knowledge is the supreme purifier, realized through disciplined practice and yoga.

39.original_verse: The one with faith, the one who is devoted, and the one who controls their senses, gains knowledge; having gained knowledge, one attains supreme peace quickly.
39.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Faith, devotion, and self-control are prerequisites for knowledge, which leads to inner peace.

40.original_verse: The ignorant and faithless person, of doubting nature, perishes. Neither this world, nor the next, nor happiness is there for the doubting soul.
40.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Doubt and lack of faith obstruct spiritual progress, leading to loss in both this life and the afterlife.

41.original_verse: The one who has renounced actions through yoga, whose doubts are torn asunder by knowledge, is poised in the Self and is not bound by actions.
41.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Knowledge and yoga dissolve doubts, anchoring one in the Self and freeing them from bondage to actions.

42.original_verse: Therefore, with the sword of knowledge, cut asunder the doubt born of ignorance residing in your heart. Be established in yoga and rise, O Scion of Bharata.
42.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Knowledge is the weapon to overcome ignorance; yoga and determination lead to liberation.

4.original_verse: Children, not the wise, speak of Sānkhya and Karma-Yog as different. He who is truly established in one obtains the results of both.
4.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: The paths of Sānkhya (knowledge) and Karma-Yog (action) are ultimately complementary. Krishna highlights the harmony between intellectual realization and practical engagement.

5.original_verse: The State that is reached by the Sānkhyas is also reached by the yogīs. He truly sees who sees Sānkhya and Karma-Yog as one.
5.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna stresses the unified goal of liberation through both paths, encouraging integration of knowledge and action.

6.original_verse: But renunciation, O mighty-armed one, is hard to attain without Karma-Yog. The meditative man equipped with Yog attains Brahman without delay.
6.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Action performed in the spirit of dedication aids in renunciation, as it purifies the mind and prepares one for realization of Brahman.

7.original_verse: The yogī who is devoted, pure, self-controlled, and free from material dualities is established in the Self and remains unaffected by actions.
7.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna explains that a pure and disciplined mind helps a person transcend the binding effects of actions, leading to spiritual stability.

8.original_verse: He who knows the truth about the divisions of the Self and actions realizes that he does not act, nor is he entangled by actions.
8.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Knowledge of the true nature of the Self as distinct from the body and actions frees one from identifying with actions and their results.

9.original_verse: He who sees that actions are performed by Nature alone, and that the Self is actionless, truly sees.
9.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Understanding the distinction between the impermanent body and the eternal Self leads to the realization of inaction amidst action.

10.original_verse: He who dedicates all actions to Brahman, abandoning attachment, remains untouched by sin, as a lotus leaf by water.
10.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Offering actions to Brahman while renouncing attachment ensures purity and freedom from the effects of karma.

11.original_verse: By giving up attachment, yogīs undertake work with body, mind, intellect, and even the senses, for self-purification.
11.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Renouncing attachment to results and focusing on self-purification transforms mundane work into a path to liberation.

12.original_verse: The resolute yogī, having renounced the fruits of work, attains peace, while the unsteady, driven by desire, is bound by actions.
12.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Detachment from the fruits of action is key to inner peace, while attachment causes entanglement in the cycle of karma.

13.original_verse: The embodied being, having renounced actions mentally, dwells happily in the city of nine gates, neither acting nor causing to act.
13.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna uses the metaphor of the body as a city with nine gates to describe the Self's detachment from physical and mental actions.

14.original_verse: The Self does not create agentship or actions, nor does it associate with the fruits of actions. It is Nature that acts.
14.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Actions are driven by Nature (Prakriti), not the Self, which remains untouched and eternal.

15.original_verse: The Omnipresent neither accepts sin nor virtue. Knowledge is covered by ignorance, and thus beings are deluded.
15.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Ignorance obscures the true knowledge of the Self, causing beings to err and suffer in the material world.

16.original_verse: But among those whose ignorance of the Self is destroyed by wisdom, their wisdom illuminates the highest, like the sun.
16.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Wisdom removes the veil of ignorance, allowing the eternal truth of the Self to shine forth as brightly as the sun.

17.original_verse: Those whose insight is that, whose selves are that, whose grounding is that, who hold that as highest, and whose evils are shaken off by wisdom, do not go to another birth.
17.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: With minds fixed on the supreme reality, such individuals transcend rebirth, shedding all evils through knowledge.

18.original_verse: The pandits see the same – in a Brahmin, gifted with knowledge and training, as in a cow or an elephant, as in a dog or a dog-cooker.
18.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: True wisdom sees the universal essence in all beings, irrespective of their societal distinctions or physical forms.

19.original_verse: Rebirth is conquered here in this world by those whose minds abide in that sameness; Brahman has no fault, and so they abide in Brahman.
19.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Attaining equanimity and realizing the faultless nature of Brahman leads to liberation from the cycle of birth and death.

20.original_verse: When one finds something loved, one shouldn’t be excited; when one finds something unloved, one shouldn’t tremble. With insight firm, without confusion, knowing Brahman, one abides in Brahman.
20.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Steadfastness and equanimity in both joy and sorrow reveal one's alignment with Brahman.

21.original_verse: The one who does not cling to sensations from the outside, who finds joy in the self, and who joins with Brahman through yoga, reaches endless joy.
21.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: True joy is eternal and arises from detachment and inner alignment with Brahman through yoga.

22.original_verse: Son of Kunti, pleasures born of sensations are like wombs filled with pain; they have a beginning and an end, so the wise one does not rejoice in them.
22.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Material pleasures are fleeting and inherently linked to suffering; wisdom seeks lasting contentment beyond these.

23.original_verse: One who can endure in this world the shock that begins in desire and anger, before release from the body, is joined to yoga and a happy person.
23.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Self-control over desires and anger leads to happiness and prepares one for liberation.

24.original_verse: The one who practises yoga, who has joy within, delight within, and then radiance within, thus reaches cessation in Brahman, of one being with Brahman.
24.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Inner joy and light achieved through yoga bring liberation and union with Brahman.

25.original_verse: The sages reach cessation in Brahman; their evils destroyed, their dualities cut, their selves restrained, they rejoice in the friendship of all beings.
25.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Restraint, purification, and universal compassion lead to liberation in Brahman.

26.original_verse: Cessation in Brahman lies nearby for those ascetics who are restrained, who are not joined to anger and desire, who are restrained in thought and who know the self.
26.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Freedom from anger and desire, combined with self-realization, ensures liberation in Brahman.

27.original_verse: Making outside sensation truly outside, focusing the eye between the eyebrows, making equal the ingoing breath and the outgoing breath, moving in the nose.
27.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Meditative focus and breath control are pathways to inner peace and spiritual awakening.

28.original_verse: The sage whose highest path is release, whose sense, mind, and insight are controlled, whose anger, fear, and longing have disappeared, is always released.
28.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Mastery over the senses and emotions leads to eternal liberation.

29.original_verse: That sage attains peace who knows me as the enjoyer of the heated disciplines of sacrifice, as great lord of the whole world, as one whose heart is with all beings.
29.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Understanding Krishna as the ultimate benefactor and friend of all beings brings profound peace and fulfillment.

1.original_verse: The Blessed Lord said: He who performs his bounden duty without depending on the fruits of actions, he is a renouncer and also a devotee, and not he who is without fire and without action.
1.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: A true renouncer and yogi is one who acts without attachment to results, as opposed to one who merely gives up external actions.

2.original_verse: Know that to be called renunciation which is Yoga; for none becomes a yogi who has not renounced the thought of results of action.
2.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Yoga is the unification of the mind, attainable through renunciation of desires for results.

3.original_verse: For a sage who is desirous of ascending to Yoga, action is said to be the means; when he has ascended to Yoga, inaction is said to be the means.
3.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Initial discipline involves action, but later realization leads to transcendence and non-attachment to actions.

4.original_verse: When a man is unattached to objects of sense or to actions, having renounced all thoughts, then he is said to have ascended to Yoga.
4.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Detachment from the sensory and mental realms is a marker of yogic ascension.

5.original_verse: One should raise oneself by oneself; one should not let oneself sink; for oneself is verily one's own friend, oneself is verily one's own enemy.
5.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Self-effort is crucial for spiritual progress; the mind can act as an ally or adversary depending on discipline.

6.original_verse: For him who has conquered himself by himself, his own self is his friend. But for him who has not conquered himself, his own self acts as his enemy.
6.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Mastery over oneself brings harmony; failure to do so results in inner conflict.

7.original_verse: The supreme Self of him who is self-controlled and serene is balanced in cold and heat, pleasure and pain, and also in honour and dishonour.
7.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Equanimity in the face of dualities is a hallmark of yogic discipline.

8.original_verse: The yogi who is satisfied with knowledge and wisdom, who remains unshaken, who has conquered the senses, and to whom a clod of earth, a stone, and gold are alike, is said to be harmonized.
8.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: A balanced yogi treats all material forms equally, rising above attachment and aversion.

9.original_verse: He who has the same attitude towards a benefactor, friend, foe, the indifferent, the neutral, the hateful, a relative, the righteous, and even the unrighteous, excels.
9.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: True spiritual harmony sees beyond superficial distinctions between people.

10.original_verse: A yogi should constantly engage his mind in meditation, remaining in solitude, alone, with controlled mind and body, free from desires and possessions.
10.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Meditation requires focus, solitude, and freedom from material distractions.

11.original_verse: Having established in a clean place his firm seat, neither too high nor too low, made of cloth, a skin and grass, one upon the other;
11.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: The physical preparation for meditation reflects the importance of stability and purity.

12.original_verse: There, having made the mind one-pointed, with the actions of the mind and the senses controlled, let him practice Yoga for the purification of the self.
12.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Mental focus and sensory discipline are central to self-purification through Yoga.

13.original_verse: Holding the body, head, and neck erect, motionless and firm, looking at the tip of the nose and not around, let him focus his mind.
13.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Physical posture aids concentration and mental discipline in Yoga.

14.original_verse: Serene and fearless, firm in the vow of celibacy, having controlled the mind, thinking of Me and balanced, let him sit, intent on Me.
14.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Mental steadiness combined with devotion brings the yogi closer to the divine.

15.original_verse: With the mind harmonized by Yoga, the yogi, rid of sins, attains easily the infinite bliss of contact with the supreme Self.
15.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Through harmonization and purity, the yogi achieves communion with the Supreme.
